name: building construction, budget hotel | building, budget hotel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21388/documentation

This dataset represents a tourist accommodation facility located in Junín, Peru. The case study hotel is classed as budget hotel (comfort category 3 star). It was first opened in 2006 although the building where the hotel resides was constructed in 1957. Prior to becoming a hotel, the building was used as a farm. The hotel has capacity of 50 beds and offers 20 double-size rooms with double or twin beds, with additional capacity to install an extra single bed in each room in the periods of high demand and if and when required. The hotel is made up by 21 stand-alone buildings, where 20 buildings host guest rooms and 1 building represents an administrative building. All buildings have 1 floor. The load bearing structure of hotel buildings is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork. The administrative building hosts a lobby, a restaurant, a bar and a conference hall. There is a swimming pool (70 m2) and a parking lot (220 m2) for guest use on site. Laundry is available on site. The hotel occupies a total area of 420000 m2 which is the legacy of it being a farm in the past. The area in actual use (i.e. the area occupied by all hotel buildings and amenities) is 2181 m2 and the hotel"s Gross Floor Area (GFA) is 1366 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hotel is 30% which is equal to 5475 guest nights per year. The hotel"s occupancy is significantly lower than the country"s average of 66%; (Source: Hotel News Now 2015. The state of Peru"s tourism, hotels. Available from: http://www.hotelnewsnow.biz/Articles/27650/The-state-of-Perus-tourism-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018). This can in part be explained by the hotel location which is rather remote. This is also because of the hotel positioning itself as an eco-lodge which does not appeal to the mass consumer.

This dataset is modelled to include the inputs for the construction of a hotel building. This includes:energy and water used in construction, land transformation, building structure and outer building shell, inner walls, roofs, ceiling and windows, doors, floors, finishing and painting, bathroom equipment. Activities include hotel building construction with lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. Maintenance is included only through the consideration of the lifetime of the different exchanges. For example, windows are assumed to have a lifetime of 35 years, therefore the exchange amount is multiplied by 75years / 35 years=2.14. Hotel building foundation is included in the form of estimates based on the hotel area and construction practices in Peru. 


Activities end with 1 unit of hotel building, including maintenance. Due to data availability, the following building construction processes have been excluded: cables, gutter, drains.
category: F:Construction/41:Construction of buildings/410:Construction of buildings/4100:Construction of buildings

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hotel is located in Junín, Peru
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology in use is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of operations, energy and water consumption are aggregate and represent the case study hotel as a whole, rather than its specific operational areas (e.g. guest rooms, restaurant and bar). The comments to respective processes explain this in detail.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). This flow represents ceramic washing basin and ceramic toilet seat. The hotel has 26 washing basins and 29 toilet seats. Washing basins are assumed to weigh 15 kg (information taken from IKEA (2018) for the product "TÖRNVIKEN Countertop wash-basin", source retrieved from: http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/products/washstands-taps/wash-basins/t%C3%B6rnviken-countertop-wash-basin-white-art-90291518/, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Toilet seats are assumed to weigh 35 kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product "COOKE & LEWIS FABIENNE CLOSE-COUPLED TOILET WITH SOFT CLOSE SEAT", source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-fabienne-close-coupled-toilet-with-soft-close-seat/1142804_BQ.prd?B/R_Toilets_C_CT, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to inert waste.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Amount of output material is set equal to the amount of respective input material, concrete, normal. It also includes waste clay brick and waste concrete from hotel foundation. For waste concrete, conversion is made from m3 of concrete to kg of concrete based on the wet mass property of concrete (see properties section).

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Used here in place of the floor material. No data on the type of flooring was provided by the case study hotel so PVC was used as proxy. This is because PVC flooring is most cost-effective for hotels. Source: Mikulski 2015. TOP HOSPITALITY FLOORING OPTIONS FOR HOTELS. Available from: http://www.businessflooring.net/blog/top-hospitality-flooring-options-for-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018. Combined of all instances of use across the building. Assumed density of PVC 2.3 kg/m2. Source: The colour flooring company 2018. VINYL FLOORING TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS. Available from: https://www.colourflooring.co.uk/pages/vinyl-flooring-technical-specifications Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of PVC floors is 40 years. Source: Bowyer et al. 2009. LIFE CYCLE ASSESSMENT OF FLOORING MATERIALS A GUIDE TO INTELLIGENT SELECTION. Doviteil Partners. Available from: http://www.dovetailinc.org/report_pdfs/2009/dovetailfloors0809.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to waste PVC.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Used here in place of water soluble acrylic paint. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls. Assuming 1 liter of paint is required to paint 10 m2 and weighs 1.5 kg. Source:  BQ 2018. Wall painting calculator. Available from: https://www.diy.com/help-advice/wall-painting-calculator/Dev_npcart_100008.art Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of 5 years which is equivalent to the period of major refurbishments in hotels. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19(17-18), 1917-1930. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste concrete.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Assuming that 0.5 kl per 1 m2 of floor area (GFA) is required in building construction. Source: Crawford et al. 2005. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. Value double checked in McCormack, et al. 2007.

Reference:

Crawford, Robert and Treloar, Graham 2005, An assessment of the energy and water embodied in commercial building construction, in Australian Life Cycle Assessment Conference (4th : 2005 : Novotel, Sydney, N.S.W.), Australian Life Cycle Assessment Society, Sydney, N.S.W., pp. 1-10.

McCormack, et al. 2007. Modelling direct and indirect water requirements of construction. Building research & information. 35(2), 156-162.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls (1015.8m3). Assumed thickness of concrete of 225 mm. Source: Insulation 2011. Thermafloor TF70. INSULATION FOR SOLID CONCRETE AND SUSPENDED GROUND FLOORS. Available from http://kingspaninsulation.co.uk/getattachment/5fdd04b2-e58e-4622-97bb-5861799ab02a/Thermafloor-TF70-pdf.pdf Accessed 23 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout.

Additionally the concrete for foundations is accounted for (120m3). Estimated value based on the hotel area and construction practices in Peru. The foundation is assumed to be 480 m long, 0.5 m wide and 0.5 m deep. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste concrete.
